attributes.action: Ban Fishing and Fish Farming
attributes.background: 200 million tons of fish are produced for food each year, both from the wild and from fish farms. Fish are sentient beings; they feel pain, like we mammals do. They are not vegetables. They have lives that matter. Also, overfishing is ruining the ecosystems and decimating fish populations.
attributes.additional_details:
Fish do not deserve to be caught. They deserve to have their lives respected, just as we would respect the life of a dog or cat, or another human, or our own life.
 
Overfishing also depletes fish stocks available to seabirds and other ocean predators.
 
We need to stop catching and killing fish, and also farming fish. We need to let the oceans and their wildlife recover and stop the violence against innocent fish.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Stop water pollution in the Lake District
attributes.background: I want there should be a ban on water pollution in the Lake District world heritage site. I was disgusted to find out that raw sewage was allowed to flow into Lake Windermere for 1700 hours in 2020 as part of the overflow system at Ambleside waste management plant.
attributes.additional_details: I believe this issue requires governmental intervention to make it law and to hold those who do pollute the lakes, rivers and waters to be held accountable. I want the rivers and lakes to be clean for the people that utilise them and especially for the wildlife that call the Lake District home.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

Decisions about managing pollution in the Lake District are a matter for the relevant local authorities and environmental agencies, not the Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Ban Water Companies discharging raw sewage into water courses: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/582336

attributes.action: UK Environmental Protection Act
attributes.background: Create & implement a UK wide environmental protection act. To preserve, restore and protect the UK and worldwide climate. Implementing rules, guidelines and sanctions for all businesses, general public, government and public services. To protect the health of individuals and the environment.
attributes.additional_details: To guide and build the public and businesses into a sustainable economy that protects and preserves the environment. It is the only way to ensure true sustainability. To make the move needed to reduce global warming and dangerous climate change that will have detrimental effects on economies, migration, crops, wildlife, disease, and many more factors. Human driven climate change is the biggest danger to our lives in the near future and change needs to happen. The UK should lead the way.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the environment, but we're not sure exactly what new laws you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

An Environment Bill, to make provision about targets, plans and policies for improving the natural environment; for statements and reports about environmental protection; for the Office for Environmental Protection; about waste and resource efficiency; about air quality; for the recall of products that fail to meet environmental standards; about water; about nature and biodiversity; for conservation covenants; about the regulation of chemicals; and for connected purposes, is already being considered by Parliament. You can find out more about this Bill here: https://bills.parliament.uk/bills/2593

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Ban the sale of fireworks to the public
attributes.background: I would like parliament to consider the banning of fireworks to the general public. I believe only council organised displays should have access to fireworks.
attributes.additional_details: Back garden displays are selfish and inconsiderate. Many people dread bonfire night approaching every year. The affects to some animals are fatal. Fireworks also have a negative impact on the environment and the wildlife. There is evidence of them causing upset to the elderly, newborns, vulnerable people and people suffering from dementia, as well as household pets. I don’t believe that the sale of such items should be for sale and so easily accessible to the public.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: To provide urgent aid and support for the recent ecological crisis in Mauritius
attributes.background: The Mauritian Prime Minister requested urgent international aid after a ship carrying nearly 4000 tonnes of oil began leaking in the ocean. With 1000 tonnes of oil leaked and over 2500 tonnes still onboard, the situation is dire and the government are strained and under-equipped to contain it.
attributes.additional_details: An ecological catastrophe is imminent with coral reefs, wildlife and beaches at high risk as well as the livelihoods of the tourism and fishing dependent locals. Mauritius is a commonwealth country with strong UK trade relations. With a proportionately sizeable Mauritian diaspora community living in the UK and British expat community in Mauritius and more urgently, the environmental crisis on hand, it is in the public interest to provide aid and support as a priority and a matter of urgency.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334440

attributes.action: Close the Royal Parks to vehicle traffic
attributes.background:
Since government restrictions the parks have been a new haven for all to enjoy exercise safely and pollution free.

In particular Bushey Park. Wheelchair users and those in mobility vehicles have been out in largenumbers.
attributes.additional_details: Debate the need for cars to be in these areas. We have valuable wildlife and deer roaming. With pollution a focus point, there needs to be freedom from the car in these places.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Ban the planting of alien plant species to provide cover for gamebirds.
attributes.background: While thousands of volunteers and millions of pounds are being used to clear wildlife threatening alien species such as Japanese knotweed and giant hogweed others such as snowberry and cherry laurel are still being planted out to give non native gamebirds such as pheasant shelter!
attributes.additional_details: There is already a massive conservation problem with invasive plants such as rhododendron that were historically used to provide shelter for gamebirds which have now spread and become invasive species suppressing native fauna and flora. Unfortunately the shooting community is not helping conservationists remedy previous mistakes by clearing them, but is instead continuing to plant more such as snowberry and cherry laurel! This irresponsible practice must be stopped.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure whether you want to ban all non-native species in the UK or just in specifc circumstances. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Remove the ‘right to roam’ status currently applicable to domesticated Cats
attributes.background: Update the law around domestic cats, removing their "right to roam" status, putting the onus on cat owners to take responsibility for any nuisance to, or loss of enjoyment of, land, private property and wildlife. Cats should fall under the same laws applying to dogs and other domesticated animals.
attributes.additional_details:
A: Cats kill an estimated 27 million birds/fledglings each breeding season (RSPB). We should be protecting our wildlife during a critical time for many species. Two species they predate are in serious decline; House sparrows (71%) and Starlings (66%). The Mammal Society's Domestic Cats Predation on Wildlife research says 100 million prey items are taken by cats each season. 
B: Environmental protection laws being passed to save species, yet cats permitted to roam with the privilege to destroy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a recycle system like Pfand in germany.
attributes.background: I would like that we introduce this system as it encourages people to recycle and it helps influence people to stop littering as the bottles/cans they have in their hand holds value. In Germany, it is effective and i see no cans/bottles on the floor.
attributes.additional_details: I want the government to do this as it would help towards recycling and keeping the country clean, litterless, and the oceans/rivers/lakes clean. I believe that if people are given an incentive to do this, then it would influence people to do the right thing for the country and its wildlife. I believe ,as a young person, that people my age will be more likely to recycle, as wll as their families, if they know that recycling hold value instead of just shunning the fact we are killing the earth.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/572535

attributes.action: License grouse moors and repurpose some for rewilding to aid biodiversity
attributes.background:
Implement limited grouse moor licenses, with a zero tolerance license loss for heather burning and predator persecution. 

In areas with many grouse moors or where nature needs more aid, do not issue licenses and repurpose the land for rewilding through the RSPB, Wildlife Trusts, and other parties
attributes.additional_details:
Grouse moors cover over 6 million acres of land in the UK. Intensive management has a massive negative effect on the natural world, disrupting peat bogs which lock up carbon (or emit carbon when drained), deforestation, and killing raptors through cruel methods. They have failed in self regulation.

Introducing a license for England and Wales would force good standards. If these standards not met, the vast amounts of land can be repurposed for rewilding, to meet the 2050 Net Zero target.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about activities relating to grouse moors, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

It's not sure exactly what you want to be licensed, or how proposals for rewilding would work where a moor is privately owned.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Replace the Landfill Tax with a waste premium
attributes.background:
The 1996 introduction of Landfill Tax has had the unintended consequences of incentivising fly tipping.
 
We should replace Landfill Tax with a waste premium rewarding the delivery of separated waste at recycling, processing and storage centres.
attributes.additional_details:
Our countryside and cities are blighted with unsightly and often dangerous waste from fly tipping and general littering. Our local authorities are paying for ineffective cleaning up.
 
Placing a value on the delivery of sorted waste at designated recycling, processing and storage centres could help transform our environment, save our wildlife, keep us safe and save money.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Raise littering fines to encourage people to use the bins provided.
attributes.background: Raise the current littering fines to a substantial sum. This will make people think twice before throwing litter from car windows or not using the provided bins when out walking.
attributes.additional_details: To help the natural environment, help protect wildlife from pollution and to make the towns and countryside a more healthy and beeter place to be.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334297

attributes.action: Start a discussion to ban the public sale of fireworks.
attributes.background:
Start a discussion to ban the public sale of fireworks and prohibit displays to lisenced events.

Unlisenced public use of fireworks is dangerous, a public inconvenience, polluting and antisocial.

They harm animals both wild and domestic.
attributes.additional_details:
I would be greatful for the government to discuss tougher controls on the public sale of fireworks and the consequences for the miss use of such explosives.

Fireworks are becoming antisocial and dangerous.  The constant banging at this time of year is detrimental to peoples mental health and to the well-being of pets, domestic animals and wildlife.

Restricting the sale of such explosives to lisenced professionals who conduct appropriate risk assessments before an event is essential to safety

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: Give local areas the right to protect wild life, green spaces and marine life.
attributes.background: This petition calls for the parliamentary debate on Government planning policy on green spaces, that will have a detrimental effect on local wild life, marine life and natural habitats.
attributes.additional_details:
It will protect an established green space that is a natural habitat for many different species of 
wildlife, marine life, plants and birds.

rejection.details:
Local authorities already have powers to protect wild life and designate green areas, and have a public authority duty to have regard to conserving biodiversity.

We could accept a petition calling for local authorities to be given new powers, or have new obligations, but it would need to be clear what changes you want to be made to current arrangements.

attributes.action: Ban the BANG!
attributes.background: To only allow silent fireworks to be sold at private and public events so all animals domesticated and wildlife do not have to be scared, frightened, and petrified to death. #NO MORE BANGS!
attributes.additional_details: Stop the sale of all fireworks with noise, silent fireworks only.

rejection.details:
All fireworks make some noise, but we have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Reduce the decibel limit on fireworks to 85 decibels, to reduce impact: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/622900

attributes.action: Change the law on fireworks
attributes.background:
Discontinue the manufacture and sale of fireworks to the public and only allow organised displays. 
In addition, only have silent fireworks at these displays; silent fireworks are able to be made and there’s no reason why people can’t enjoy shows without the awful noise that terrifies so many.
attributes.additional_details:
Every year bonfire night comes around and weeks before and weeks after, fireworks are set off; scaring wild animals and pets, particularly dogs and horses.  This year already, prior to bonfire night, there’s been a horse who has jumped out of its field onto a motorway, injuring himself and a driver as he landed on a car. 
There’s been dogs that have ran away from their gardens or on walks because they have been terrified, not to mention the dogs that sit at home barking and shaking with fear. 
There’s wildlife animals who can’t escape it.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign:
'Ban sale of fireworks to the public and limit sales to licensed displays only'
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616868

'Reduce the decibel limit on fireworks to 85 decibels, to reduce impact'
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/622900

attributes.action: Legislate the sale and use of explosive fireworks
attributes.background: BAN EXPLOSIVE FIREWORKS.  I speak on behalf of my neighbourhood community who speak of having their roof damaged by a rather explosive "cherry bomb". I also speak on behalf of our pets, local wildlife, our elderly and PTSD sufferers (who remember the REAL bombs!) and couples with babies.
attributes.additional_details: I refer to the "cherry bombs" or "firecrackers" that emanate a very loud bang or boom.  I believe there is a need to investigate/reseach into, the importation/purchase of already-illegal fireworks that end up in communities, scaring pets, wildlife and damaging property. Furthermore, the setting off of fireworks continues WELL past the 5th November. This is an archaic tradition.  Firework vendors also pop up, and disappear soon after, without consequence, setting up shop in local village centres.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Stop the sale of fireworks to the general public: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557780

Ban the use of all fireworks in order to reduce air and noise pollution: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334448

attributes.action: Introduce legislation  for silent fireworks only.
attributes.background:
Introduce legislation to only allow the sale of silent fireworks and only permit silent fireworks in displays.

They can be traumatic for children with hyper sensitive hearing and pets are particularly prone to noise phobia.
attributes.additional_details:
We propose introducing a law likened to what they have in Collecchio, Italy which endeavours to reduce the stress on pets and local wildlife, and it also means that pet owners can join in the celebrations rather than staying home to comfort scared pets.

The fireworks displays can still be impressive visual displays that all can enjoy.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549758

While some fireworks are marketed as silent, these still make some noise. If you would like the Government to reduce the decibel limit to a specific level, you could start a new petition requesting this.

We have also published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Limit the Sale and Use of Fireworks to Organisers of Licensed Displays Only: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

Ban the use of all fireworks in order to reduce air and noise pollution: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334448

attributes.action: Make single-use face masks biodegradable
attributes.background: Change the production of single-use face masks that are available to the general public to make them biodegradable.
attributes.additional_details: Too many facemasks are making their way into our oceans. Not only does this cause catastrophic issues for a wildlife and marine life, tiny microplastic particles make their way into food supply and contaminate human food produce. If even only 1 percent of single use masks were disposed of incorrectly, this would result in 10 million masks per month dispersed in the environment. The weight of each mask is about 4 grams, this results in more than 40 thousand kilograms of plastic in nature.

rejection.details:
The Government is not responsible for the production of face masks, this is a matter for individual producers.

We have accepted the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Ban the sale of disposable face masks to the general public: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549832

Ban the use of disposable face masks and plastic gloves in public places: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324857

attributes.action: Ban the use of Palm oil in products on sale in the UK.
attributes.background: I want the Government to ban or significantly reduce the use of products containg Palm oil imported and sold in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
The effects of deforestation are well documented. 

As consumers we are providing a demand for products containing Palm oil which will and is currently destroying the homes and natural habitats of wildlife. 

The Government can help slow down and possibly prevent the extinction of exotic species by seizing our contribution to the demand of Palm oil which is responsible for killing our wildlife and damaging our planet.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/308368

attributes.action: Ban the use of sky lanterns.
attributes.background:
We would like the sale and use of sky (Chinese) lanterns banned in the United Kingdom. These small lanterns use naked flames to enable the lantern to float into the sky. They cannot be controlled and as a result can fall anywhere.

We would like it to be against the law to sell or use these.
attributes.additional_details:
Sky lanterns are dangerous as the cannot be controlled, they can fall anywhere and have been responsible for starting numerous fires. They have also landed on livestock causing serious injuries to animals, meaning some have had to be euthanised. 

The remains often contain wires which in themselves can cause injuries to wildlife, as well as causing pollution.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310556

attributes.action: Protect our zoos, wildlife parks and aquariums during the corona virus pandemix
attributes.background: Our zoos, wildlife parks and aquariums etc are in danger of closing, and this puts the animals in their care in danger also. Some of the UKs and the worlds most endangered species reside in our zoos. They need support while their main income (visitors) is closed off. Our zoos are now endangered.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and aquariums are now at the start of there best time of year for them. With the nicer weather zoos etc get more and more people through their gates. This is their biggest income stream, BUT due to lockdown they can not open, and they are missing out on VITAL funds

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/308733

attributes.action: Introduce A Scheme Where People Are Paid At Least £5 for Every Tree They Plant
attributes.background: The climate crisis is imminently serious and the Government and people in general are not taking it seriously enough. The rainforests are being destroyed. The ice is melting. Animals are going extinct. People’s health is failing and people are actually dying because of this crisis.
attributes.additional_details:
Trees are an amazing asset to help tackle the climate crisis and ensure the continued existence of life on Earth. They take in carbon dioxide and produce oxygen that we all need to breathe. They reduce pollution. They also provide homes and food for animals.
 A financial incentive for everyone to plant more trees could greatly benefit native wildlife and the air we all need!
 Just think of how many more trees would be planted if people were paid at least £5 for every tree they planted!

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make roadside verges protected wildlife & wildflower habitats for biodiversity
attributes.background: We request a cross-party agreement & legal statute affording special protection to all of our roadsides verges - urban & rural - so that the management regimes of verges better enhance biodiversity and protect native wildflowers. Also, to make it a legal requirement to collect cuttings after mowing
attributes.additional_details:
Across 315,000+ miles of roadways, almost half of our total native wildflower and flora species exist. Inconsiderate maintenance regimes are harming our native wildflowers due to cutting too often & leaving behind those cuttings and cutting at the wrong time harming annual wildflowers, eg.  forgetting how nature can help us with Yellow Rattle.

By affording verges protection nationally, requirements would be placed on local authorities and contractors to maintain for wildflowers & biodiversity.

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Require local authorities replace roadside grass with wild flowers: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616394

Fund the planting of wildflowers along all public green spaces: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607277

attributes.action: Stop Farnborough Civic Quarter development plans to cut 237 trees!
attributes.background:
We the constituents of Rushmoor District object to the unnecessary destruction of 237 mature trees which would take place if RBC's current plan for the development of Farnborough Civic Quarter goes ahead. 
This action conflicts with RBC's own Local Plan and adversely impacts the community:
attributes.additional_details:
The trees provide shade combating the urban heat-island effect.

They absorb C02 and felling them means the loss of carbon sinks combating climate change. 

Decrease in air quality close to the airport.

People living in the town centre will be affected by noise pollution.

A lack of green spaces has a negative effect on people's mental health. 

It will cause a huge loss of biodiversity and habitat for wildlife.

We are challenging this development on the grounds of RBC's own Local Plan.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about local developments are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

Rushmoor Borough Council also has its own petitions scheme, which you can find out about here: https://www.rushmoor.gov.uk/media/h5ioha4n/12_-_new_petitions_scheme.pdf

attributes.action: Save the seals,  ban the sale of flying rings.
attributes.background:
Every year, seals are rescued with discarded or lost plastic flying rings embedded into their necks. These are the ones which are found and have a chance of being nursed back to health, unfortunately,  many aren't so lucky and go on to suffer agonising deaths. 
Sign and share to help save the seals
attributes.additional_details:
Please discuss the possibility of banning the sale of flying rings.
Whilst playing with flying rings is fun and involves healthy outdoor exercise,  it's not worth the risk. 
Most people would not intentionally harm a seal or any wildlife but might not be aware of the dangers.
Thankyou.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/331386

attributes.action: Provide financial aid for charitable organisations during the Corvid 19 outbreak
attributes.background: Make sure that charitable organisations are protected and get financial assistance from the Government to compensate for their loss of earnings during the Corvid 19 lockdown.
attributes.additional_details: The Government has provided aid to businesses during the Corvid 19 outbreak but not to charitable organisations.  Charities come in different forms, whether helping vulnerable people, protecting animals and wildlife, or historic sites and attractions.  Normally they would be able to generate income from shops, fundraising activities or visitors to their venues but this won't happen while everyone in isolation.  It is vital they they do not loose out because of this unfortunate situation.

rejection.details:
Since you started your petition the Government has announced a £750 million package of support for charities, including grants for smaller charities. The Government has also said it will match fund whatever the public decides to donate to the BBC’s Big Night In charity appeal on 23 April: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/chancellor-sets-out-extra-750-million-coronavirus-funding-for-frontline-charities

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here:
https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/ 

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak. 
 
Find out more and watch the Committee put questions suggested by petitioners to Government Ministers and the Deputy Chief Medical Officer: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/news/145767/committee-question-deputy-chief-medical-officer-and-ministers-on-coronavirus-response/
 
Read letters asking further questions of Government Ministers: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/

attributes.action: Ban the manufacturing, sale, and import of disposable vape pens in the UK
attributes.background: 168 million disposable vape pens are sold annually in the UK, with a significant number of discarded vapes not even making it to landfill; they are increasingly found in our streets, rivers, and seas, where they pose a threat to our ecosystem. As they gain popularity, the issue will get worse.
attributes.additional_details: Not only do vapes contain plastic, but also   metals in the battery and heating element, including 0.15g of lithium. Lithium can be toxic to wildlife, and there is evidence that both domestic and wild animals are attracted to chemicals found in vapes, which animals will seek out and chew with potentially lethal outcomes. Lithium is also rare, and is a vital component for batteries which are used for more useful devices, such as laptops and mobile phones. We should not be wasted it in vapes.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/628115

attributes.action: Stop the new build site close to Whitby Abbey, Whitby, North Yorkshire
attributes.background:
STOP NEW HOME BUILD ON LAND NEAR WHITBY ABBEY.
60+ new homes are to be build on land near Whitby Abbey despite objections from residents.
Whitby Town Council have objected to the plans, with “concerns over highways and access, community safety and impact on the character of the local area”.
attributes.additional_details: This is a historic building and needs protecting along with the surrounding area which is home to wildlife and insects.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a decision for the local authority.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Stop the use of glue traps to catch animals as it kills them
attributes.background: Consider the use of glue traps on animals as it is killing all wildlife it is in humane and wrong. The glue will rip off any skin or fur causing an endless amount of pain to the animal trapped. Not to mention the fact that they slowly starve. There’s more humane ways to catch rodents.
attributes.additional_details: Despite it being used for rats, other animals like robins and cats get stuck and they lose their life, even though the intent was for a rat. It should be banned for catching all wildlife

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petition:

Make glue traps illegal within the UK
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/560288

attributes.action: Issue guidance that birdwatching is a permitted as exercise under lockdown
attributes.background: Ministers to give specific guidance to police, like those for fishing and hunting, on Covid lockdown restrictions, that allow local birdwatching, nature watching and photography as a specifically allowed form of exercise, while adhering to the rules on gathering limits and social distancing
attributes.additional_details:
Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport have told the Angling Trust fishing is allowed as exercise so long as participants adhere to the rules on staying local, gathering limits, social distancing & limiting the time spent outdoors
Similar guidance on hunting has also been issued to hunting orgs
Birdwatchers however have been stopped by police & told they are in breach of restrictions for simply stopping to look at wildlife, which is no more a risk than using a gun or sitting with a rod

rejection.details:
Since you started your petition the Government has stated that people can leave their home to exercise or to visit a public outdoor place for outdoor recreation: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/national-lockdown-stay-at-home

The Government's guidance does not specifically refer to particular activities.

attributes.action: Stop destroying wildlife habitats
attributes.background: Thousands of homes are built around the UK if this carries on we won't have any green belt woodland or countryside left. All wildlife habitat will be destroyed and wildlife animals will be pushed to extinction.
attributes.additional_details: Tell them to put a stop to the thousands of homes been built everywhere. the cause of these problems are by illegal immigrants entering the UK they are pushing up the population

rejection.details:
It is not clear what you are asking the Government to do. A number of legislative instruments and guidelines already set out the restrictions imposed upon builders and developers relating to wildlife habitats.

Planning decisions are a matter for local authorities, and not the Government or House of Commons.

You could start a petition calling on the Government to change specific measures that already exist in respect of wildlife habitats when new homes are being planned, but would need to be clear what changes you want the Government to make.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of sky lanterns
attributes.background:
Ban the use and sale of sky lanterns, also known as Kongming lanterns, or Chinese lanterns, in the United Kingdom.  
These lanterns cause fires and are a hazard to wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Sky lanterns can cause suffering or even kill animals and livestock.   Some of the key dangers are:
Animals eating lantern debris which can cause tears or punctures to internal organs leading to a potentially life-threatening situation
Animals getting splinters in their skin which may cause infection
Animals becoming trapped or tangled in debris
They can also cause fires when they land.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310556

attributes.action: Ban the public sale of fireworks and restrict only to organised events
attributes.background:
I propose Fireworks be limited to be bought by organised events and banned from public general sale. 
The effect they have on humans and animals regularly increases stress levels and can often be deadly. The use of Fireworks against police on Halloween also could have been so much worse.
attributes.additional_details:
The effect the Firework noises have on our pets, wildlife and people suffering with PTSD is massive, sometimes deadly. Its heartbreakng watching the suffering these noises cause, knowing there is nothing that can be done to stop it.
Limiting purchasing to organised events would restrict the amount of nights these noises can go off, allowing everyone to prepare more on just 1 or 2 nights, rather than the random nights/days they are currently set off over several weeks. Prolonging stress levels.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616868

attributes.action: Ban the use and sale of rat poison
attributes.background:
We need to get a ban on the use and sale of rat poison after pets have accidentally eaten it. People have used it to purposely poison pets by throwing it in gardens and streets!
This is despicable and something needs to change to stop this happening. Our pets and children are at risk!
attributes.additional_details: Ban the use and sale of poisons to stop our children, pets and wildlife being at risk of malicious or accidental poisoning which can, and has, lead to death!

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/615605

attributes.action: Save Wethersfield Airfield
attributes.background: The Government is reneging on commitments in the Environment Act to stop the decline of wildlife by proposing to develop two mega-prisons on the site of the old Wethersfield airfield, which has become an important space for nature near Braintree, Essex.
attributes.additional_details: Some 74 species of birds, many Red-listed, nest nearby and the area comprises 75,000 trees and shrubs. The site also includes ancient woodland, as well as Great Crested Newts and rare orchids. Red-listed birds on the site include European Turtle Dove, Northern Lapwing and Grey Partridge.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the prospect of new prisons being built around RAF Wethersfield, but we're not sure if you want the Government to commit to not building these prisons here, or take some other action or actions regarding this site.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Ban the use of free-running snares for trapping wildlife.
attributes.background: While the war on wildlife is a worldwide issue, snares are without doubt an element of that war! There are non-lethal ways of managing conflicts with wild animals like foxes, including better fencing and scent-based deterrents. There is no justification for the use of cruel devices like snares.
attributes.additional_details:
Every year 1.7 million animals are trapped in snares in the UK. 70% of the animals trapped in these vicious snares are non-target species. Snares don’t discriminate and a wide range of species are caught in snares, Cats and dogs are routinely caught in them. 

People setting free-running snares cannot ensure animal welfare as required under the Animal Welfare Act 2006, that such snares cause unnecessary suffering to mammals, are indiscriminate and should be banned.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/600593

attributes.action: Ban the sale of noisy fireworks to the public and keep for organised displays
attributes.background: Ban the sale of noisy fireworks to the general public, and keep them only for organised displays but allow the sale of silent/lower noise fireworks to the public.
attributes.additional_details:
Every year thousands of households let fireworks off, and every year the nation becomes divided between people who have pets and people who don’t. Banning the sale of noisy fireworks to the general public allows households to still let off silent fireworks and enjoy the celebrations but also stops the unnecessary stress, harm, and death that it brings to pets, wildlife, and also people coping with things such as PTSD. 

Only allow organised displays to have noisy fireworks.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549758

While some fireworks are marketed as silent, these still make some noise. If you would like the Government to reduce the decibel limit to a specific level, you could start a new petition requesting this.

We have also published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Limit the Sale and Use of Fireworks to Organisers of Licensed Displays Only: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

Ban the use of all fireworks in order to reduce air and noise pollution: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334448

attributes.action: Ban the the sale of fireworks to the general public.
attributes.background: To ban all sales of fireworks to the general public and only be sold to organised events.
attributes.additional_details: Because it distresses animals and wildlife. They are let off at all times of the year and at crazy times at night and sometimes even the day.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: Allow the public a vote on whether they want HS2 or not.
attributes.background:
We live in a democratic society; yet HS2 has been thrust on us without asking us whether we want it or not. The public should decide on whether they want this project to go ahead.

The project has already negatively impacted so many people's lives and will continue to do so for many years.
attributes.additional_details: The government should allow the public a vote on whether they want HS2 to continue. It is affecting so many lives, but people have had no choice. It is destroying important wildlife habitats, fauna, historical buildings and burial sites. They allowed a vote on Brexit. People should also have an opportunity to vote on whether they want the face of their landscape, and the areas in which they live, to change. In a democratic society, you should allow people a choice and not dictate.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/326850

attributes.action: Let zoo's and wildlife parks Reopen as soon as possible
attributes.background: Let the zoo's and wildlife parks open as soon as possible. If shops can open why not zoo's
attributes.additional_details: Zoo's need our money to care for the animals in their care. They should not have to decide which animals they chose to feed. We are suppose to be a nation of animal lovers.

attributes.action: Make it illegal to release Chinese or flying lanterns
attributes.background: The government works hard to provide a thriving farming economy which this country should be proud of whilst it also has a booming equine industry. Chinese or flying lanterns cause pain, suffering and death for many of these harmless animals. To see them banned would put a stop to this.
attributes.additional_details:
The RSPCA reported “
An estimated 200,000 sky lanterns are sold and released each year in the UK. As the popularity of these items increase, so does the risk to wildlife. They also cause injury and suffering to animals and have a devastating impact on the environment.
There have been reports of animals becoming entangled in these lanterns and becoming injured trying to free themselves, which will cause extreme stress and suffering.” This is before discussing Ingestion  off them and wild fires.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310556

attributes.action: save the moravian settlement from being sold and destroyed.
attributes.background: The council in the area of Droylsden is planning on selling and building on the Love lane woodland and Scout area. We want you to stop this sale as this area is used by scouts and local people as a safe place and community area.
attributes.additional_details: This area is precious to many people such as children, young adults and the elderly. We want to protect our wildlife, and our community to increase community cohesion and overall sense of pride in the place we live. The abundance of trees provide clean air and stop flooding and it is the last remaining wooded area we have. More houses means more traffic in an over crowded area which is already at full capacity. This is a conservation area and it just be just that: conserved.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about disposal of local authority assets are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Ban ballon release
attributes.background: Ban the release of ballon’s in groups
attributes.additional_details: This is detrimental to the environment and kills wildlife

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a similar action:

Make releasing helium balloons and sky lanterns a specific littering offence: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/609032

attributes.action: I want parliament to stop Sweden from culling wolves.
attributes.background: I want Government and Parliament to talk to the Swedish government and ask them to not cull any wolves. There are only 480 wolves in Sweden. Do you want innocent animals to die? It breaks a law set by the EU to protect endangered species. 27 countries agreed to this. Why would we do for cattle?
attributes.additional_details: In Yellowstone park wolves were eradicated but this left many problems for wildlife. Without wolves beavers couldn’t build dams, fish were unprotected, rivers were eroded. Elks overgrazed. But when biologists reintroduced wolves it had an amazing effect on the ecosystem. Mammals came back, songbirds sang again, beavers built dams. The world isn’t as picturesque without wolves. The ecosystem suffered without wolves. Imagine what’ll happen to Sweden? For a bunch of cattle. Is it really worth it?

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about whether to cull the wolf population of Sweden are a matter for the Swedish government, not the UK Government or Parliament.

attributes.action: Stop the sell of fireworks to the general public!
attributes.background: To stop unorganised firework displays, it’s a cruel torture against animals that can easily be avoided. Too many animals have lost their life to irresponsible humans setting off fireworks close to their home and fields of livestock.
attributes.additional_details:
Fireworks are a dangerous weapon that anyone can buy over the age of 18 without any prior knowledge to their use or impact. 
We need to encourage protection of our animals and wildlife by creating a law that fireworks are only allowed at organised displays on the night of the 5 November! 
Too many animals are losing their lives and being unnecessarily scared because of an act that can easily be stopped, that can be controlled to one night a year.

rejection.details:

Make fireworks illegal to buy, with the exception of public displays.
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591501

attributes.action: Ban the wholesale of fireworks
attributes.background: To only allow organised displays on or around the 5th of November and New Year.
attributes.additional_details: It is unfair to frighten nervous pets, to farm animals and wildlife to be subjected to the constant explosive sound all year round. It is a form of noise pollution that is unchecked and un policed.

rejection.details:

Make fireworks illegal to buy, with the exception of public displays:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591501

attributes.action: Stop the removal of the ban on usage of neonicotinoids post-Brexit.
attributes.background: Stop the removal of the ban on usage of neonicotinoids in British farming post-Brexit to protect the bees and other pollinators in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: The use of neonicotinoids has a devastating impact on the bee population which is already at risk. We’ve lost a third of the bee population in the UK in the last decade - we cannot let it be further decimated by the usage of these harmful pesticides. This ban which was previously supported by the UK parliament is being revoked now that we are exiting the EU, and will have a horrendous impact on the pollinators in UK wildlife if it is allowed to continue.

rejection.details:

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Increased enforcement and penalties for littering and advertising campaign
attributes.background: There has been a large increase of street waste due to the inconsiderate minority not picking up dog waste and discarding their face coverings and gloves.  Harsher penalties which are more strictly enforced are needed.  Increase the penalties and recruit more wardens to police and enforce them.
attributes.additional_details: The conscientious majority are making absolutely no headway against the inconsiderate and filthy minority who discard picnic leftovers, drink bottles and cans, disposable face masks and gloves, don't pick up after their dogs, unwrap, drop wrapper and eat when they leave a shop and many more.  This shows zero consideration for other people, livestock, wildlife or the environment. The Government must  take this seriously and bring in harsher penalties, then recruit more people to enforce them.

attributes.background: Millions of citizens need to be occupied and being able to nurture plants and vegetables is a way to allow them to be at home and occupied without being tempted to go out and potentially spread the virus. Garden centres have large open car parks where customers can collect on line orders safely.
attributes.additional_details: Apart from the social wellbeing of many retired and enforced furlowed gardeners this will create, keep happy and give a sense of achievement, there is a strong economic case for these businesses to remain open and therefore viable. Wildlife and pollinators e.g. bees also need gardens.
